I don't think it's a bad example, but I think it's a bad example to use when explaining the difference between OOP and functional programming.
In the first case, you have a function that takes an array and produces a result. In the second case, you have a function that takes an array, an integer, and a string, and produces a result.
The first one is more "functional" in the sense that it's more about functions taking other functions as arguments, but the second one is more "functional" in the sense that it's more about functions taking a function as an argument.

This is a good example of a poor algorithm.
It is O(n^2) in the number of elements of the array, and the worst case is O(n!) if you're unlucky.
This is particularly bad when you consider that the naive solution is O(n), and the algorithm that the OP used is O(n log n).
I would recommend reading up on the Knuth–Morris–Pratt algorithm for sorting.

You're right, and I should have said that the algorithm is O(n log n) _in the worst case_.
The Knuth–Morris–Pratt algorithm is O(n log n) in the average case, and O(n) in the worst case.

The Knuth-Morris-Pratt algorithm is O(n log n) in the _worst_ case, but it is also O(n log n) in the _average_ case. It's O(n) in the _best_ case.
